title: Víctor Neumann-Lara
text:
Víctor Neumann-Lara (1933–2004) was a Mexican <a href="mathematician">mathematician</a>, pioneer in the field of <a href="graph%20theory">graph theory</a> in <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>. His work also covers <a href="general%20topology">general topology</a>, <a href="game%20theory">game theory</a> and <a href="combinatorics">combinatorics</a>.
Biography.
Born in the city of <a href="Huejutla%20de%20Reyes">Huejutla de Reyes</a>, <a href="Hidalgo%20%28Mexico%29">Hidalgo</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, he soon moved to <a href="Mexico%20City">Mexico City</a>, where he received his bachelor's degree in <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a> from the School of Sciences, <a href="National%20Autonomous%20University%20of%20Mexico">UNAM</a>.
His life was greatly devoted to teaching, giving over 100 courses in Mexico and around the world, and introducing new <a href="teaching%20method">teaching method</a>s. He carried color chalks with him all the time, and was prompt to give graphic explanations.
Work.
Full Professor at Institute of Mathematics, <a href="UNAM">UNAM</a>, he directed over 15 theses and taught both in the Institute and in the Faculty of Sciences. Below is a selection of his multiple publications, which earned him over 120 citations from renowned mathematicians in the area of graph theory.
In 1982 he introduced the notion of dichromatic number of a <a href="directed%20graph">digraph</a>, which will eventually be used in kernel theory and <a href="tournament%20theory">tournament theory</a>.
